data.title: Salzgitter Funding Boost Puts Hydrogen Steel And Green Premiums In Focus
data.description:
• Germany has approved a substantial supplementary public funding tranche for Salzgitter's hydrogen steel initiative.
  • The support strengthens one of the country's key industrial decarbonisation projects in the steel sector.
  • The funding approval comes with backing from the European Commission, providing additional regulatory certainty.

Salzgitter (XTRA:SZG) is a major German steel producer, and its hydrogen based steel initiative sits at the center of wider efforts to cut industrial emissions. Steelmaking is one of the more carbon intensive sectors, so public funding for low carbon production technologies is becoming an important theme for policymakers and large emitters alike.

For investors, the new funding round raises questions around execution timelines, capital needs, and potential long term cost structures for cleaner steel. It also puts Salzgitter more clearly on the map in discussions about supply chains for low carbon materials and the role of policy support in reshaping heavy industry.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Salzgitter by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Salzgitter.

2 things going right for Salzgitter that this headline doesn't cover.

The ‚Ç¨379.9 million supplementary funding, lifting total public support for the Salcos project to about ‚Ç¨1.5b, reduces financing pressure on Salzgitter for a capital intensive transition that is estimated at roughly $3b. For you as an investor, that means a larger share of the upfront risk is being absorbed by the state rather than solely through Salzgitter's balance sheet or potential equity dilution. With European Commission approval already in place, regulatory risk around state aid also looks more contained, which can matter for long lead time industrial projects.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Salzgitter Narrative

  • The extra funding directly backs the green steel and SALCOS initiatives mentioned in the narrative, supporting the idea that regulatory support could underpin more stable margins and potential green premium pricing.
  • Execution risk around restructuring and large capex, already flagged in the narrative, could still challenge the medium term earnings bridge if project costs rise or timelines slip, even with public money covering more than half the budget.
  • The targeted 95% reduction in direct CO‚ÇÇ emissions at full build out and the link to carbon border costs for global buyers are not fully captured in the existing storyline and could influence long term demand from customers focused on low CO‚ÇÇ steel.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Salzgitter to help decide what it is worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Large, multi year capex still needs to be executed on time and on budget, and any setbacks could strain cash flow or require additional funding.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Competition from other European and global steelmakers such as ArcelorMittal and Thyssenkrupp, many of which are pursuing their own low CO‚ÇÇ projects, may limit pricing power for green steel if supply grows faster than demand.
  • üéÅ Public funds covering more than half of the planned Salcos spend ease the financial burden on Salzgitter and support its position in low carbon steel as carbon regulation and customer requirements tighten.
  • üéÅ If buyers start to factor carbon border costs and emissions more heavily into sourcing decisions, Salzgitter's targeted 95% cut in direct CO‚ÇÇ emissions could make its steel more attractive in global supply chains.

What To Watch Going Forward

You may want to watch how Salzgitter phases the remaining Salcos investments, including any updates on total project cost, commissioning milestones, and contract wins for low CO‚ÇÇ products. Progress on securing long term offtake agreements with automotive, construction, and machinery customers will be important to see whether policy support translates into commercial traction. It is also worth tracking how peers such as ArcelorMittal and Thyssenkrupp advance their own hydrogen or low CO‚ÇÇ steel projects, as this will shape how differentiated Salzgitter really is.

New Found Gold is currently trading on a P/B of 12.8x, which screens as good value against its peer group average of 67.2x but looks expensive next to the broader Canadian metals and mining industry average of 3.9x.

P/B compares the market value of the company to its book value, which can be a useful cross check for early stage explorers where earnings are negative and traditional profit based multiples are less informative. For New Found Gold, this makes the balance sheet the key anchor, rather than current profits, given the company is still loss making with net income of CA$45.9m loss and no meaningful revenue reported.

The P/E ratio compares the current share price with earnings per share. A 19.1x multiple effectively indicates how much the market is paying for each unit of current earnings. For a metals and mining name that is not a bank, this is a common way to benchmark sentiment around the earnings stream.

However, Aichi Steel‚Äôs P/E of 19.1x is described as expensive relative to both the JP Metals and Mining industry average of 14.5x and a peer average of 11.8x. At the same time, our DCF model, which projects future cash flows and discounts them back to today, points to a very large gap between the current ¬•3,505 price and a theoretical ¬•63,651.95 value.

data.title: Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) Narrower Q4 Loss Tests Bullish Earnings Ramp Narrative
data.description:
Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) closed out FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$134.3 million and a basic EPS loss of US$0.03, alongside net income excluding extra items of a US$2.0 million loss. This puts the focus squarely on how efficiently that top line is being converted into earnings. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$65.2 million in Q3 2024 to US$100.3 million in Q4 2024, then to US$99.9 million in Q1 2025, US$103.0 million in Q2 2025, US$118.6 million in Q3 2025 and US$134.3 million in Q4 2025. Over those same periods, basic EPS ranged from a loss of US$2.60 to a loss of US$0.03, setting up a story where revenue momentum is bumping up against still pressured margins.

See our full analysis for Applied Optoelectronics.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this mix of growing revenue and ongoing losses lines up with the widely followed growth and risk narratives around AAOI, and where those stories might need updating.

See what the community is saying about Applied Optoelectronics

Advertisement

US$455.7m in sales still paired with TTM loss

  • On a trailing twelve month basis, AAOI generated US$455.7 million in revenue and reported a net loss excluding extra items of US$38.2 million, with TTM basic EPS at a loss of US$0.64.
  • Consensus narrative expects revenue to grow 51.5% per year with margins moving from a loss of 42.3% to an 8.7% profit margin over three years, yet the latest TTM loss and negative EPS show that the company is still in the loss making phase today.
    • Analysts see earnings shifting from a loss of US$155.7 million to a profit of US$111.0 million by around 2028, while the most recent TTM net loss of US$38.2 million indicates a smaller loss than that reference point but still not a profit.
    • This gap between current losses and future profit expectations is a key part of the consensus view, which links the current revenue base of US$455.7 million to much higher forecast revenue of US$1.3b.

Loss trend vs high growth forecasts

  • Over the last twelve months AAOI remained unprofitable and its losses have grown at about 21.6% per year over the past five years, even as revenue is forecast to grow 57% per year and earnings are forecast to rise at 140.91% per year with profitability expected within three years.
  • Bulls argue that rapid adoption of 400G and 800G products, plus margin expansion from vertical integration, can support this strong earnings ramp, but the history of growing losses gives a very different reference point.
    • The bullish narrative points to margins moving from a 42.3% loss to an 18.6% profit margin and earnings reaching US$318.0 million, which sits in sharp contrast to the recent TTM net loss of US$38.2 million and five year loss growth rate of 21.6% a year.
    • Supporters also assume revenue rising to about US$1.7b, a multiple of the current US$455.7 million TTM level, so the thesis relies on the business scaling several times larger while reversing a multiyear loss pattern.
Have bulls already priced in a best case ramp for AAOI, or is the current loss history masking future earnings power in plain sight? üêÇ Applied Optoelectronics Bull Case

Rich P/S multiple and dilution risks

  • The shares trade on a P/S of 13.9x compared with 1.9x for the broader US Communications industry and 2.8x for peers, while shareholders have also faced substantial dilution over the past year alongside a DCF fair value estimate of US$109.22 that sits well above the current share price of US$84.23.
  • Bears focus on that high multiple and dilution, arguing that dependence on a small number of large customers and heavy capital needs leave limited room for error even if revenue continues to grow.
    • With the top 10 customers accounting for 98% of revenue and two customers making up 88%, the high P/S of 13.9x is being supported by a concentrated revenue base rather than a broad mix of customers.
    • Ongoing expectations for share count to grow 7% per year over the next three years also line up with the recent dilution, which can spread any future earnings recovery over a larger number of shares.
If AAOI needs years of high spending and faces concentrated customers, some investors may question whether this valuation and dilution mix leaves enough margin for safety. üêª Applied Optoelectronics Bear Case

data.description:

The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$3.1b and EPS of US$0.08 in Q4 2024 to US$3.6b and EPS of US$0.24 in Q4 2025, with trailing twelve month EPS at US$0.53 and net income of US$106.3m on US$12.9b in revenue.   • Within FY 2025, basic EPS moved from roughly US$0.05 in Q1 and Q2 to US$0.19 in Q3 and US$0.24 in Q4, alongside revenue rising from US$2.9b to US$3.6b over the same period.
  • Bulls argue that operational improvements and specialty pharmacy momentum can keep lifting margins, and the step up in quarterly EPS speaks to that argument, but with some caveats:
    • Net income, excluding extra items, increased from about US$9.7m in Q1 to US$49.3m in Q4, which strongly supports the bullish idea that the model can generate higher profit as volume scales.

data.description:
Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) has capped FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$9.5b and a basic EPS loss of US$0.10, setting the tone for a year where profitability on a trailing basis has been supported by a sizeable one off gain. The company has seen quarterly revenue range between US$9.0b and US$9.8b across 2025, with EPS swinging from a loss of US$0.18 in Q1 to a profit of US$0.64 in Q2 before reverting to losses in Q3 and Q4. This leaves investors focusing on how much of the reported margin profile is driven by recurring operations versus that single US$2.4b boost. Overall, the latest numbers present a mixed margin picture that puts quality and durability of earnings at the centre of the earnings debate.

See our full analysis for Warner Bros. Discovery.

With the headline figures on the table, the next step is to set these results against the prevailing Warner Bros. Discovery narratives to see which stories about growth, profitability and risk still hold up and which ones the numbers start to challenge.

See what the community is saying about Warner Bros. Discovery

Advertisement

Profitability helped by US$2.4b one off gain

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, Warner Bros. Discovery reports Basic EPS of US$0.29 and net income of US$727 million on US$37.3b of revenue, with management indicating that a single US$2.4b gain is a key part of that profit picture.
  • Bulls argue that expanding use of franchises like Harry Potter, DC, Lord of the Rings and broader monetization of the content library can sustain earnings beyond this. However, the reliance on a large one off gain means investors have to separate recurring profitability from that US$2.4b boost.
    • The bullish narrative points to multi channel revenue from theatrical, streaming, gaming, merchandise and experiences as support for earnings, while the latest year still shows three loss making quarters at the EPS level.
    • Supporters of the bullish view highlight international expansion and partnerships, but the mixed quarterly net income profile, with Q1, Q3 and Q4 all reporting losses, gives a more cautious backdrop for those long term assumptions.

Bulls who think the content engine can outgrow that US$2.4b one off gain may want to see how that optimistic storyline stacks up against the full set of assumptions in the dedicated bull case for Warner Bros. Discovery. üêÇ Warner Bros. Discovery Bull Case

High P/E and modest growth forecasts

  • The trailing P/E sits at 96.1x compared with 37x for the US Entertainment industry and 39.9x for peers, while forecasts call for earnings growth of about 9.3% per year and revenue growth of about 1.2% per year.
  • Consensus narrative suggests that leveraging iconic IP and global sports plus cost discipline can support higher margins and cash flow. Yet the combination of a high P/E and modest growth expectations gives that story a relatively tight margin for error.
    • Analysts expecting roughly 9.3% annual earnings growth are effectively asking the current 96.1x P/E to be supported by mid single digit style earnings growth and low single digit revenue growth.
    • At the same time, revenue growth forecasts of about 1.2% per year running behind broader US market expectations sit awkwardly next to a P/E that is more than double the industry average.

Debt costs sit against weak interest coverage

  • Analysts flag that interest payments are not well covered by earnings, which is a major financial risk even though the company has reported US$727 million of trailing 12 month net income and positive EPS on that basis.
  • Bears argue that heavy debt, rising content costs and streaming competition could compress margins further, and the weak interest coverage data point gives that cautious view solid grounding.
    • The fact that interest is not well covered comes alongside a mixed quarterly earnings record for FY 2025, with three out of four quarters showing net losses even before extra items.
    • Critics highlight that if earnings growth comes in below the roughly 9.3% forecast, the company would have less flexibility to handle interest costs that are already described as not well covered.

Investors who focus on balance sheet resilience and the risk around interest coverage may want to see how the cautious camp lays out its arguments in the dedicated bear case for Warner Bros. Discovery. üêª Warner Bros. Discovery Bear Case

Next Steps

To see how these results tie into long-term growth, risks, and valuation, check out the full range of community narratives for Warner Bros. Discovery on Simply Wall St. Add the company to your watchlist or portfolio so you'll be alerted when the story evolves.

After weighing both the bullish and cautious angles, the real question is how you see the balance between risk and reward. Move quickly, review the underlying data yourself and let our breakdown of 3 key rewards and 2 important warning signs help you form a clear view.

See What Else Is Out There

WBD combines a very high 96.1x P/E, modest forecast growth and weak interest coverage, with profitability heavily influenced by a single US$2.4b gain.

data.title: Is It Time To Reassess Viavi Solutions (VIAV) After Its Recent Share Price Surge
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Viavi Solutions' share price still lines up with its fundamentals, this article will walk through what the current market price might be implying about value.
  • At a last close of US$29.71, the stock has recent returns of 7.9% over 7 days, 41.3% over 30 days, 63.7% year to date, 165.7% over 1 year and 177.4% over 3 years, compared with 91.2% over 5 years.
  • Recent news coverage has focused on Viavi Solutions' position within communications test and measurement and its role in supporting network build outs and technology rollouts. This helps frame how investors might think about the business backdrop to these returns. Commentary has also highlighted how investors are paying closer attention to companies exposed to connectivity and network infrastructure, which can influence how the market prices risk and potential.
  • Despite these share price moves, Viavi Solutions holds a valuation score of 1 out of 6, so we will look at what different approaches like P/E, multiples and cash flow based estimates suggest about the current price. We then finish with a broader way of thinking about value that can round out those numbers.

Viavi Solutions scores just 1/6 on our valuation checks. See what other red flags we found in the full valuation breakdown.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Viavi Solutions Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model looks at the cash Viavi Solutions is expected to generate in the future and discounts those projections back to today using a required rate of return. The idea is to estimate what all those future cash flows are worth in today's dollars.

For Viavi Solutions, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The latest twelve month free cash flow is about $74.64 million. Analyst and extrapolated projections, provided in the model, run out to 2035 and show free cash flow estimates reaching $536.31 million in that year, all expressed in US$ and then discounted back to the present.

Pulling those discounted cash flows together, the model arrives at an estimated intrinsic value of about US$29.42 per share. Against a recent market price of US$29.71, the DCF suggests the stock is around 1.0% overvalued, which is a very small gap and well within any reasonable margin of error.

Result: ABOUT RIGHT

Viavi Solutions is fairly valued according to our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF), but this can change at a moment's notice. Track the value in your watchlist or portfolio and be alerted on when to act.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Viavi Solutions.

Approach 2: Viavi Solutions Price vs Sales

For a company like Viavi Solutions, where investors often focus on revenue rather than net income, the P/S ratio is a useful way to think about what you are paying for each dollar of sales. Higher expected growth and lower perceived risk usually justify a higher P/S multiple. In contrast, slower expected growth or higher risk tend to pull that ‚Äúnormal‚Äù range down.

Viavi Solutions currently trades on a P/S of 5.53x. That sits above both the Communications industry average P/S of 1.92x and the peer average of 2.91x, so the market is attaching a richer sales multiple than these broad benchmarks.

Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio for Viavi Solutions is 6.07x. This is a proprietary estimate of what the P/S might be given factors such as earnings growth, profit margins, industry, market cap and specific risks. Because it looks at these company level characteristics rather than just simple peer or industry comparisons, it can give a more tailored sense of what ‚Äúfair‚Äù could look like.

Putting that beside the current 5.53x P/S, Viavi Solutions is priced below the 6.07x Fair Ratio on this metric.

Result: UNDERVALUED

You can link your view of its future revenue, earnings and margins to a forecast and fair value, then compare that fair value with the current price to help decide when to buy or sell. data.title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Cancer Advances Test Valuation Gap For Investors
data.description:
• Bristol-Myers Squibb (NYSE:BMY) and SystImmune report highly positive Phase 3 interim results for izalontamab brengitecan in advanced triple-negative breast cancer.
  • The trial shows significant gains in progression-free survival and overall survival for patients in a hard-to-treat cancer setting.
  • The FDA accepts the new drug application for iberdomide for multiple myeloma, granting Breakthrough Therapy Designation and Priority Review.
  • Iberdomide is described as a first-in-class cereblon E3 ligase modulator for patients with multiple myeloma.

data.title: Ziff Davis Refocuses On Core Business As RetailMeNot Bets On Cash Back
data.description:
• RetailMeNot, a Ziff Davis (NasdaqGS:ZD) company, has launched a Guaranteed Cash Back program that offers assured and stackable rewards for shoppers.
  • Ziff Davis completed its exit from the Games Publishing business in Q4 2025, refocusing on its core operations.

For you as an investor, these moves sit at the heart of what Ziff Davis does today: a mix of digital media, subscription based services, and advertising supported platforms. RetailMeNot‚Äôs Guaranteed Cash Back program reflects how retailers and brands are trying to keep customers engaged, and measurable performance marketing tools remain a key focus across the sector.

The exit from Games Publishing removes a more content heavy, project driven activity from the NasdaqGS:ZD portfolio and aligns the company more tightly with its existing core operations. Together, these developments may influence how the business allocates capital across segments and how steady or variable its future revenue mix may look.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Ziff Davis by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Ziff Davis.

We've flagged 1 risk for Ziff Davis. See which could impact your investment.

For Ziff Davis, RetailMeNot‚Äôs Guaranteed Cash Back rollout looks like an attempt to steady the Tech & Shopping segment after an 18% Q4 revenue decline linked to weaker search traffic and affiliate commissions. A guaranteed 1% cash back across more than 4,000 merchants, some funded directly by RetailMeNot, gives retailers a clearer, performance based offer and could help shift the business mix from pure traffic driven affiliate revenues toward more direct, relationship based marketing spend. That may matter if search referrals remain pressured or if competitors such as Groupon and Honey keep pushing aggressive offers to retailers and brands.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Ziff Davis Narrative

  • The focus on RetailMeNot and exiting Games Publishing aligns with the narrative that Ziff Davis is concentrating on higher margin, recurring digital services and performance marketing, in line with its emphasis on SaaS like and subscription based revenue streams.
  • The weak Q4, flat to slightly negative near term revenue commentary, and Tech & Shopping headwinds challenge the idea that all core verticals can easily support ongoing revenue and margin expansion without further pressure.
  • The Guaranteed Cash Back program and the decision to fully exit Games Publishing, while retaining rights to potential future performance payments, add more detail on how management is reacting to traffic shifts and AI driven content changes, which is not fully captured in the earlier high level growth narrative.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Ziff Davis to help decide what it is worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Q4 2025 net income fell sharply to US$0.37 million from US$64.09 million a year earlier, which shows how quickly profitability can compress when key segments weaken and one off items hit results.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è The 18% revenue decline in Tech & Shopping and management‚Äôs decision to defer 2026 guidance highlight uncertainty around search traffic trends, AI content licensing outcomes, and how quickly the company can adjust its model.
  • üéÅ Full year 2025 revenue of US$1.45b versus US$1.40b a year earlier, strong free cash flow, and US$174 million in buybacks, including 30.48% of shares repurchased since 2020, show that Ziff Davis is using cash generation to reshape its capital structure.
  • üéÅ Growth in Health & Wellness, Connectivity, and Cybersecurity & Martech, helped by AI powered data tools and increased pharma ad spend, suggests the company has businesses that are less dependent on search engine referrals than Tech & Shopping.

What To Watch Going Forward

As a shareholder or potential investor, you may want to watch how quickly RetailMeNot‚Äôs Guaranteed Cash Back program translates into steadier Tech & Shopping revenue, especially if search referral volumes stay under pressure. The company‚Äôs ongoing talks around AI content licensing with large platforms could influence both traffic and monetization, so any updates there will matter. It is also worth tracking whether management continues to exit or shrink lower return activities, similar to Games Publishing, and how that affects margins and earnings over the next few quarters. Finally, with share repurchases already reducing the share count by more than 10% in 2025, future capital allocation decisions, including any extension of the buyback program, will likely remain a key part of the story.
